Quantum Computing Strategy
← Back to dashboard
Strategy Overview

Investing in the Quantum Revolution ⚛️

A detailed, pure-play hardware strategy using a "Differentiated Modality" approach to capture venture-scale upside from the transition to commercially relevant quantum advantage.

Universe: Pure-play quantum hardware
Instruments: IONQ, QBTS, RGTI, QUBT
Horizon: 7–10 years (2026–2035)
Structure: Modality-diversified sleeve

Core Investment Thesis

Venture-scale upside

The quantum computing industry is at a critical inflection point, transitioning from theoretical research to demonstrable commercial value—a milestone known as "Quantum Advantage". This transition presents a rare opportunity for asymmetric, venture-scale returns that are largely uncorrelated with the broader technology market.

The Quantum Imperative

  • Validation trigger: Achieving Quantum Advantage—solving a commercially relevant problem better than a classical supercomputer—acts as a powerful de-risking signal, likely to trigger a substantial, non-linear re-rating of valuations as enterprise customers and institutional investors move from observation to active deployment.
  • Undiluted exposure: While giants such as Google and IBM hold strong internal quantum efforts, the financial impact is diluted. Pure-play companies offer direct, undiluted exposure where success is tightly coupled to industry progress, creating the potential for multi-bagger outcomes.

The strategy assumes that this dynamic creates a high-probability setup for significant value creation as we move through the second half of this decade and into the early 2030s.

Timelines & Execution

  • Deployment (2026): The full capital allocation is deployed at the start of 2026. Current valuations do not fully price in the non-linear upside of a near-term Quantum Advantage event, which could trigger a rapid and significant re-rating.
  • Drawdown (7–10 years): Value realisation is expected once fault-tolerant systems generate meaningful, recurring revenue, projected for the early 2030s. The strategy is designed around a 7–10 year holding period, with gradual drawdown as the thesis matures.

"Differentiated Modality" Structure

Single theme, multi-path

Rather than betting on a single "winner," the strategy allocates across the primary technological pathways to reduce single-modality risk while maintaining exposure to a breakthrough in any leading architecture.

Strategic modality sleeves

Modality Description Target share
Trapped-Ion Technology leader with superior qubit fidelity and stability, critical for error correction and early fault-tolerant systems. 40%
Quantum Annealing First-mover with demonstrated near-term commercial applications in optimisation, offering clearer line-of-sight to revenue. 30%
Superconducting A mature and scalable pathway, widely adopted by industry majors, with well-understood engineering and manufacturing dynamics. 20%
Photonic Higher-risk, differentiated architecture operating at (or near) room temperature, with potential for disruptive deployment advantages. 10%

Modality bands are expressed within this dedicated quantum sleeve; overall portfolio sizing remains a separate decision at the multi-asset level.

Suggested Asset Allocation

Pure-play hardware exposure

Capital is allocated to four curated pure-play hardware pioneers, each representing a distinct modality. The structure mirrors the modality bands above and preserves all original allocation assumptions.

Investment Ticker Modality Target allocation
IonQ IONQ Trapped-Ion 40%
D-Wave Quantum QBTS Quantum Annealing 30%
Rigetti Computing RGTI Superconducting 20%
Quantum Computing Inc. QUBT Photonic 10%

Within the quantum sleeve, allocations are fixed at inception. Rebalancing is driven by structural thesis shifts (e.g., modality obsolescence), not short-term price moves.

Prime Investment Candidates

Curated pure-play line-up

The original qualitative write-ups for each company are preserved and re-framed as a consistent card grid for model consumption.

IonQ (NYSE: IONQ)

Trapped-Ion leader

A direct bet on the pre-eminent pure-play pursuing what is arguably the most promising modality for fault-tolerant quantum computing.

Investment thesis

IonQ combines technical leadership in qubit quality with a formidable balance sheet and strategic M&A. Together, these position the firm as one of the most likely pure-plays to survive and emerge as a long-term market leader in fault-tolerant systems.

D-Wave Quantum (NYSE: QBTS)

Commercial annealing pioneer

The most de-risked pure-play from a commercialisation standpoint, using specialised annealers to solve high-value optimisation problems today.

Investment thesis

D-Wave’s "value today" proposition creates a clearer path to near-term revenue, which can help fund longer-term R&D in universal gate-based systems with reduced reliance on dilutive financing.

Rigetti Computing (NASDAQ: RGTI)

Superconducting full-stack

A leveraged bet on the eventual dominance of the superconducting modality, with a differentiated, vertically integrated manufacturing stack.

Investment thesis

Rigetti’s in-house chip manufacturing offers potential margin advantages and strategic positioning as "picks-and-shovels" infrastructure to the wider quantum ecosystem if superconducting architectures scale as expected.

Quantum Computing Inc. (NASDAQ: QUBT)

High-risk photonic

A high-risk, high-reward speculative allocation on a potentially disruptive technological path: scalable, room-temperature quantum computing.

Investment thesis

A credible breakthrough would be a game-changer, dramatically lowering deployment barriers. The "moonshot" is underwritten by a large capital raise, providing a multi-year runway to attempt commercialisation.

Scenario Framework & Portfolio Performance

Deep-tech regime risk

The quantum sleeve is evaluated under three scenarios—Bear, Neutral and Bull— each with explicit assumptions, probabilities and synthesised year-on-year portfolio returns based on the 40/30/20/10 allocation.

Bear scenario – 25% probability ("Quantum Winter")

Assumptions: Quantum Advantage is not credibly demonstrated until after 2029. Fundamental physics roadblocks prove more difficult than anticipated, pushing fault-tolerance timelines beyond 2032. Investor enthusiasm wanes, leading to a funding crisis and a period of depressed valuations across the sector.

Probability rationale: Reflects the non-trivial technical and scientific risk that deep-tech programmes stall, leading to a prolonged "winter" similar to past AI and semiconductor cycles.

Neutral scenario – 50% probability (base case)

Assumptions: First credible Quantum Advantage on a commercially relevant problem is demonstrated by 2026–2027. Early fault-tolerant systems emerge around 2029–2030, and multiple hardware modalities find viable commercial niches.

Probability rationale: Assigned the highest probability as it aligns with publicly stated, peer-reviewed roadmaps from major industry players (e.g., IBM, Quantinuum) and the broader research community.

Bull scenario – 25% probability (breakthrough)

Assumptions: Quantum Advantage is demonstrated by early 2026. A breakthrough in error correction dramatically shortens the timeline to fault-tolerance (pre-2028), and one hardware modality proves clearly superior, driving rapid market consolidation and value creation.

Probability rationale: Captures the upside potential for a structural breakthrough in physics or engineering—an outcome that, while not base case, is characteristic of deep-tech development histories.

They illustrate how the diversified modality strategy may behave under each macro scenario; they are not guarantees. Years marked with an asterisk (*) represent the drawdown phase in which exposure may be reduced as the thesis matures.

Key Risks & Intended Use by a Model

Deep-tech risk stack

The original strategy identified four core risk clusters. They are preserved here and paired with guidance on how a model should interpret and monitor the quantum sleeve.

Key risks

Risk Channel
Technical & scientific risk Breakthroughs in non-portfolio modalities (e.g., neutral atoms), stalled progress in error correction, or fundamental scalability roadblocks could render one or more chosen technologies obsolete.
Commercial & market risk A significant delay (beyond ~24 months) in demonstrating Quantum Advantage could trigger a Quantum Winter, suppressing valuations and delaying enterprise adoption.
Financial & execution risk High cash burn, repeated roadmap slips and reliance on dilutive financing create material solvency and execution risks, especially for pre‑revenue companies.
Geopolitical risk US–China export controls, shifts in government funding, or nationalisation of quantum assets could disrupt supply chains and R&D roadmaps for key players.

Intended use by a model

  • Map incoming information (technical milestones, funding events, policy shifts) to scenario probabilities and update expected portfolio paths accordingly.
  • Treat the scenario tables as illustrative stress paths rather than point forecasts; focus on direction, dispersion and drawdown characteristics.
  • Monitor modality‑level newsflow to flag potential obsolescence or dominance of a given architecture, prompting reassessment of the 40/30/20/10 split.
  • Integrate the quantum sleeve into a broader portfolio context, emphasising correlation properties, position sizing and interaction with other growth or deep‑tech exposures.
  • Track funding runway, balance sheet health and roadmap delivery as key inputs into execution and solvency risk assessment for each issuer.
